overview: From 2025-10-17 to 2025-10-18, elizaos/elizaos.github.io had 2 new PRs (1 merged), 4 new issues, and 2 active contributors.

topIssues.title: Enhancement: Add API cost estimation to ingestion pipeline
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
# Enhancement: Add API cost estimation to ingestion pipeline

## Context
Running `bun run pipeline ingest` with large date ranges can unexpectedly consume thousands of GitHub API calls, potentially hitting rate limits:
- **Authenticated users**: 5,000 requests/hour
- **GitHub Apps**: 15,000 requests/hour

This is especially problematic for:
- Historical data ingestion (e.g., `--after 2024-01-01` on 20+ repos)
- First-time project setup
- Large active repositories with thousands of PRs/issues

### Real-world example:
- **23 repositories** √ó **52 weeks** √ó **~6 API calls per week** = **~7,176 API calls**
- **Outcome**: Rate limit exhaustion, 1-2 hour wait, failed ingestion

Users need visibility into API cost before committing to large ingestions.

## Proposal
Add `--estimate-only` flag and automatic pre-flight cost estimation that shows:
- Estimated API call count
- Risk level (LOW/MEDIUM/HIGH)
- Estimated duration
- Warning for HIGH risk operations

## Implementation

### Add cost estimation function to `cli/analyze-pipeline.ts`:

```typescript
// Simple API cost estimation helper
function estimateApiCalls(
  repositories: { owner: string; name: string }[],
  intervalCount: number,
): { total: number; risk: string; duration: number } {
  const baseCallsPerRepo = intervalCount * 6; // ~6 calls per interval (PRs, issues, commits)
  const total = repositories.length * baseCallsPerRepo;

  const risk = total > 2000 ? "HIGH" : total > 500 ? "MEDIUM" : "LOW";
  const duration = Math.ceil(total / 60); // ~60 calls per minute with rate limiting

  return { total, risk, duration };
}
```

### Add CLI flag to ingest command:

```typescript
program
  .command("ingest")
  // ... existing options
  .option(
    "--estimate-only",
    "Show API cost estimation without executing ingestion",
    false,
  )
```

### Add estimation logic before execution:

```typescript
// Calculate date range and intervals
const repositories = options.repository
  ? pipelineConfig.repositories.filter(
      (r) => `${r.owner}/${r.name}` === options.repository,
    )
  : pipelineConfig.repositories;

const daysDiff =
  dateRange.endDate && dateRange.startDate
    ? Math.ceil(
        (new Date(dateRange.endDate).getTime() -
          new Date(dateRange.startDate).getTime()) /
          (1000 * 60 * 60 * 24),
      )
    : parseInt(options.days || "7");
const intervalCount = Math.ceil(daysDiff / 7); // Weekly intervals

const estimate = estimateApiCalls(repositories, intervalCount);

rootLogger.info(`üìä Cost Estimation:`, {
  repositories: repositories.length,
  intervals: intervalCount,
  estimatedApiCalls: estimate.total,
  riskLevel: estimate.risk,
  estimatedDuration: `${estimate.duration} minutes`,
});

// Handle estimate-only mode
if (options.estimateOnly) {
  console.log(`\nüìã INGESTION ESTIMATE`);
  console.log(`Repositories: ${repositories.length}`);
  console.log(`Time intervals: ${intervalCount}`);
  console.log(`Estimated API calls: ${estimate.total}`);
  console.log(`Risk level: ${estimate.risk}`);
  console.log(`Estimated duration: ${estimate.duration} minutes`);

  if (estimate.risk === "HIGH") {
    console.log(
      `\n‚ö†Ô∏è  HIGH RISK: Consider using smaller date ranges or --repository flag`,
    );
  }
  return;
}

// Warn on high-risk operations
if (estimate.risk === "HIGH") {
  rootLogger.warn(
    `‚ö†Ô∏è  High API usage detected (${estimate.total} calls). Monitor rate limits closely.`,
  );
}
```

## Benefits
- ‚úÖ Prevents accidental rate limit exhaustion
- ‚úÖ Better planning for large ingestions
- ‚úÖ User can test with `--estimate-only` before committing
- ‚úÖ Helpful for debugging and capacity planning
- ‚úÖ No behavior change for existing commands (estimation is informational)

## Trade-offs
- Estimation is approximate (actual calls may vary by ¬±20%)
- Adds ~65 lines of code total (11-line function + 1-line option + ~50 lines logic)
- Risk thresholds are somewhat arbitrary (can be tuned based on team preferences)

## Usage Examples

### Check cost before running:
```bash
$ bun run pipeline ingest --after 2024-01-01 --estimate-only

üìã INGESTION ESTIMATE
Repositories: 23
Time intervals: 52
Estimated API calls: 7,176
Risk level: HIGH
Estimated duration: 120 minutes

‚ö†Ô∏è  HIGH RISK: Consider using smaller date ranges or --repository flag
```

### Automatic estimation shown on every ingest:
```bash
$ bun run pipeline ingest --after 2024-01-01

üìä Cost Estimation: {
  repositories: 23,
  intervals: 52,
  estimatedApiCalls: 7176,
  riskLevel: 'HIGH',
  estimatedDuration: '120 minutes'
}
‚ö†Ô∏è  High API usage detected (7176 calls). Monitor rate limits closely.

Starting ingestion...
```

### Test single repo first:
```bash
$ bun run pipeline ingest --after 2024-01-01 --repository elizaos/eliza --estimate-only

üìã INGESTION ESTIMATE
Repositories: 1
Time intervals: 52
Estimated API calls: 312
Risk level: MEDIUM
Estimated duration: 6 minutes
```

## Testing
Tested with various scenarios in https://github.com/M3-org/op-hiscores:
- ‚úÖ Prevented 3 rate limit exhaustion scenarios during development
- ‚úÖ Accurate within 15% of actual API calls in 10+ test runs
- ‚úÖ Helped split large ingestions into manageable chunks

## Files Modified
- `cli/analyze-pipeline.ts` (~65 lines total: function + flag + logic)

## References
- Rate limiting best practices: https://docs.github.com/en/rest/using-the-rest-api/rate-limits-for-the-rest-api
- Original implementation: M3-org/op-hiscores post-fork commits

topIssues.title: Enhancement: Add graceful shutdown to CLI pipeline
topIssues.author: madjin

topIssues.title: Docs: Add deployment guide for forks
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
# Docs: Add deployment guide for forks

## Problem
The README doesn't document how to fork and deploy this project to GitHub Pages. Critical information missing:
- How to configure `basePath` for subdirectory deployments (e.g., `username.github.io/repo-name`)
- GitHub Pages setup steps
- Required GitHub Actions secrets beyond basic token
- Deployment architecture explanation

Currently, users who fork this repo and try to deploy to a subdirectory (the default for non-organization repos) get 404 errors for all assets because Next.js tries to load from root path instead of the subdirectory path.

## Solution
Add new "Deploying Your Own Instance" section to README after "CI/CD and Data Management" section.

### Content to add:

```markdown
## Deploying Your Own Instance

### GitHub Pages Configuration

This project deploys to the root of elizaos.github.io. If you fork this repository to deploy to a subdirectory (e.g., `username.github.io/repo-name`):

1. **Update `next.config.js`** - Add `basePath` to match your repository name:
   ```javascript
   const nextConfig = {
     output: "export",
     basePath: "/repo-name",  // Add this line - replace with your repo name
     images: {
       unoptimized: true,
     },
     typescript: {
       tsconfigPath: "tsconfig.nextjs.json",
     },
   };
   ```

2. **Enable GitHub Pages**:
   - Go to repository Settings ‚Üí Pages
   - Source: "GitHub Actions"
   - Save

3. **Add Required Secrets** (Settings ‚Üí Secrets and variables ‚Üí Actions):
   - `OPENROUTER_API_KEY` - Required for AI summary generation
   - `GITHUB_TOKEN` - Automatically provided by GitHub Actions
   - `NEXT_PUBLIC_GITHUB_CLIENT_ID` - Optional, for wallet linking feature
   - `NEXT_PUBLIC_AUTH_WORKER_URL` - Optional, for wallet linking feature

4. **Enable Workflows**:
   - Go to Actions tab
   - Enable workflows if prompted
   - Manually trigger "Run Pipelines" to generate initial data

5. **Access Your Site**:
   - Root deployment: `https://your-org.github.io/`
   - Subdirectory deployment: `https://your-username.github.io/repo-name/`

### Deployment Architecture

The site automatically deploys via GitHub Actions:
- **Data Generation**: `run-pipelines.yml` runs daily at 23:00 UTC
  - Ingests GitHub data, processes contributions, generates summaries
  - Stores data in `_data` branch (SQLite dumps, stats files, summaries)
  - Never commits large binary files to main branch
- **Site Build**: `deploy.yml` triggers on push to main or after pipeline runs
  - Restores data from `_data` branch
  - Builds Next.js static site
  - Deploys to GitHub Pages

**Note**: If deploying to a custom domain, update `basePath` in `next.config.js` accordingly (may need to remove it entirely for root domains).
```

## Impact
- ‚úÖ Clear fork deployment instructions
- ‚úÖ Prevents common 404 errors for subdirectory deployments
- ‚úÖ Documents all required secrets in one place
- ‚úÖ Explains deployment architecture for new contributors

## Testing
Documentation tested in subdirectory fork deployment: https://m3-org.github.io/op-hiscores/
Works correctly with basePath configuration.

## Implementation Notes
- Single file change: `README.md`
- Insert after "CI/CD and Data Management" section (after line ~344, before "## Development")
- No code changes required
- Clarifies that basePath is only needed for subdirectory deployments
- Explains the difference between organization/user root deploys vs subdirectory deploys

topIssues.title: Bug: Deploy workflow hardcodes single repository path
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
# Bug: Deploy workflow hardcodes single repository path

## Problem
The deploy workflow `.github/workflows/deploy.yml` line 68 hardcodes `elizaos_eliza` when copying stats files:

```yaml
- name: Get yesterday's date and copy stats
  run: |
    cp data/elizaos_eliza/stats/day/stats_$(date -d "yesterday" +'%Y-%m-%d').json data/elizaos_eliza/stats/day/stats.json
```

**Impact**: Only 1 of 23 tracked repositories gets its stats copied. The other 22 repositories (all the `elizaos-plugins_*` repos, `elizaos_auto.fun`, `elizaos_elizaos.github.io`, and `elizaos_docs`) have stale `stats.json` files.

**Current tracked repositories** (from config):
- elizaos/eliza ‚úÖ (currently working)
- elizaos/auto.fun ‚ùå
- elizaos/elizaos.github.io ‚ùå
- elizaos/docs ‚ùå
- elizaos-plugins/* (19 repos) ‚ùå

## Root Cause
The workflow was likely created when only one repository was tracked, and never updated for the multi-repo expansion.

## Solution
Replace hardcoded path with dynamic loop over all repository directories:

```yaml
- name: Copy yesterday's stats for all tracked repositories
  run: |
    YESTERDAY=$(date -d "yesterday" +'%Y-%m-%d')
    echo "Processing stats for date: ${YESTERDAY}"

    # Find all repository directories and copy stats files
    # Pattern matches owner_repo format, excluding dump/ and summaries/
    for repo_dir in data/*/; do
      repo_name=$(basename "$repo_dir")

      # Skip non-repository directories
      if [[ "$repo_name" == "dump" || "$repo_name" == "summaries" ]]; then
        continue
      fi

      stats_file="${repo_dir}stats/day/stats_${YESTERDAY}.json"
      target_file="${repo_dir}stats/day/stats.json"

      if [ -f "$stats_file" ]; then
        cp "$stats_file" "$target_file"
        echo "Copied stats for ${repo_name}"
      else
        echo "Warning: No stats file found for ${repo_name} on ${YESTERDAY}"
      fi
    done

    echo "Stats copy complete"
```

## Impact
- ‚úÖ Works with all 23 repositories
- ‚úÖ Future-proof - no need to update when repos are added/removed
- ‚úÖ Better error visibility with per-repo status messages
- ‚úÖ Skips non-repository directories (`dump`, `summaries`)
- ‚úÖ Backward compatible - existing single-repo setups continue working

## Verification
Checked current `_data` branch structure:
```bash
$ gh api 'repos/elizaOS/elizaos.github.io/git/trees/_data?recursive=1' \
  --jq '.tree[] | select(.path | test("^data/[^/]+$")) | .path'

data/dump                                    # Skip (not a repo)
data/elizaos-plugins_plugin-anthropic        # ‚úÖ Will be processed
data/elizaos-plugins_plugin-autocoder        # ‚úÖ Will be processed
... (19 more plugin repos)
data/elizaos_auto.fun                        # ‚úÖ Will be processed
data/elizaos_eliza                           # ‚úÖ Already working
data/elizaos_elizaos.github.io               # ‚úÖ Will be processed
data/elizaos_docs                            # ‚úÖ Will be processed
data/summaries                               # Skip (not a repo)
```

All repository directories follow `owner_repo` naming convention and have `stats/day/` subdirectories.

## Testing
Tested with similar multi-repo setup (14 repositories) in fork: https://github.com/M3-org/op-hiscores
- Production deployment: https://m3-org.github.io/op-hiscores/
- All 14 repos successfully processed
- See commit: 72e8955 (adapted for Optimism repos, same pattern)

## Implementation Notes
- **Single file change**: `.github/workflows/deploy.yml` (lines 68-69 ‚Üí 68-88)
- **No breaking changes**: Existing behavior preserved for `elizaos_eliza`
- **Handles edge cases**: Skips `dump` and `summaries` directories
- **Clear logging**: Shows which repos succeeded/failed
- **Safe failure mode**: Warning logged but workflow continues if stats missing

## Alternative Considered
Could use a more targeted glob pattern like `data/*_*/` to match only `owner_repo` format, but the explicit skip logic is clearer and more maintainable.

topPRs.title: docs: add deployment guide for forks
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Summary

Fixes #154

Add comprehensive deployment guide for users forking this repository to deploy their own instance.

## Problem
The README lacks documentation on:
- How to configure `basePath` for subdirectory deployments
- GitHub Pages setup steps
- Required GitHub Actions secrets
- Deployment architecture

Users forking the repo get 404 errors for all assets because Next.js tries to load from root path instead of subdirectory path.

## Solution
Added new "Deploying Your Own Instance" section after "CI/CD and Data Management" section with:

1. **basePath Configuration**: Clear instructions on when and how to add basePath to `next.config.js`
2. **GitHub Pages Setup**: Step-by-step enable instructions
3. **Required Secrets**: Complete list of secrets needed for Actions
4. **Workflow Enablement**: How to enable and trigger workflows
5. **Deployment Architecture**: Explains how `run-pipelines.yml` and `deploy.yml` work together

## Changes
- `README.md`: Added 54 lines of deployment documentation (inserted after line 344)

## Key Clarifications
- **Root deployment** (elizaos.github.io): No basePath needed
- **Subdirectory deployment** (username.github.io/repo-name): basePath required
- Explains organization vs personal account deployment differences

## Testing
‚úÖ Documentation validated against production fork deployment: https://m3-org.github.io/op-hiscores/
‚úÖ basePath configuration tested and working

## Impact
- ‚úÖ Clear fork deployment instructions
- ‚úÖ Prevents common 404 errors
- ‚úÖ Documents all required secrets in one place
- ‚úÖ Better onboarding for contributors

topPRs.title: fix: dynamically copy stats for all tracked repositories
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Summary

Fixes #153 

Replace hardcoded `elizaos_eliza` path with dynamic loop to copy stats files for all 23 tracked repositories.

## Problem
Currently only 1 of 23 repositories gets its stats copied. The workflow hardcodes `data/elizaos_eliza/stats/...` at line 68, leaving 22 other repositories with stale `stats.json` files.

## Solution
- Loop through `data/*/` directories dynamically
- Skip non-repository directories (`dump`, `summaries`)
- Add per-repository status logging
- Graceful handling if stats file is missing

## Changes
- `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`: Replace 2 lines with 27-line dynamic loop

## Testing
‚úÖ Tested with 14 repositories in production fork: https://m3-org.github.io/op-hiscores/
‚úÖ All repository stats successfully copied
‚úÖ Non-repo directories properly skipped

## Verification
Verified against current `_data` branch structure:
- 23 repository directories found
- All follow `owner_repo` naming convention
- All have `stats/day/` subdirectories

## Impact
- ‚úÖ Works with all 23 repositories
- ‚úÖ Future-proof (no hardcoded repo names)
- ‚úÖ Backward compatible
- ‚úÖ Better debugging with clear logging
